title: Yada Yada: 'Seinfeld Experience' to Come to Gramercy
summary: The immersive exhibit bills itself as a chance for fans to truly tap into the city-based sitcom's world. Some might say that New York City already is like a "Seinfeld" episode come to life. But now, the city also will play host to an immersive "Seinfeld" exhibit that bills itself as a chance for fans to truly tap into the New York-set sitcom's world.

title: Nike Posts Strong Sales, Plays Down Trade Risks
summary: CEO says sneaker giant can adjust supply chain to avoid any tariff hits. Nike Inc. posted higher sales in the latest quarter, boosted by strong demand in both the U.S. and China, and executives said the trade dispute between the two countries hasn't hurt the sneaker giant's business.

title: Biotech Companies Soar in Stock Market Debuts
summary: BridgeBio, Adaptive and Morphic find favor with investors. Investors betting on the growth prospects of life-sciences startups sent the shares of three biotechnology companies soaring in their stock market debuts on Thursday.

title: U.S. Charges Former and Current Venezuelan Electricity Officials
summary: The men were added to the U.S. sanctions list and charged with corruption, U.S. authorities say. The U.S. government stepped up pressure on Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro on Thursday, blacklisting two individuals with ties to his regime and charging them with corruption.

title: Burner Phones, Leaks to Journalists: Regulators Probe Suspected Insider-Trading Scheme
summary: Regulators in U.S., U.K. are examining what they see as a network of insider traders who exchanged tips on merger deals over a number of years. A former Citigroup Inc. employee was the alleged middleman in what authorities believe may be an insider trading scheme, according to people familiar with the matter and disclosures in a U.K. court case that wrapped up Thursday.

title: The Versailles Treaty Gets a Bum Rap
summary: The Great War's horrors, spiritual emptiness and a pack of lies made another world war inevitable.. The agreement that officially ended World War I has borne an impossibly heavy burden: The harsh terms of the Treaty of Versailles, signed on June 28, 1919, embittered Germany and set the stage for the rise of Nazism and World War II. This is mostly a myth. It was the Great War itself, not the treaty that concluded it, that set loose the forces and ideologies that would convulse Europe and initiate another global conflict.

title: Grim Lizzie
summary: Warren's odd brand of populism seeks to expand a corrupt system's power.. It's a wonder Democratic presidential candidates can face the day. To listen to them debate, they live in an America saddled with historic wealth inequality, governed by rapacious monopolies, burdened with dirty air and water. This alternate America has human-rights violations and treats women as second-class citizens. Mitch McConnell is the Most Powerful Man on the Planet.

title: Angela Davis, East Germany and Fullerton
summary: Two exhibits send conflicting messages at a university library.. Fullerton, Calif.

title: I Compete With Facebook, and It's No Monopoly
summary: Ignore the misguided calls for antitrust enforcement. Net neutrality is the way to keep social media free.. I'm chief executive officer of a social network that competes with Facebook , so you might expect I'd agree with those seeking to break up Facebook in the name of fair competition. In fact, I strongly oppose the idea. I don't believe Facebook is a monopoly.

title: The U.S. and India Stumble Toward a Trade War
summary: America has legitimate grievances, but both sides have a strategic interest in avoiding a serious conflict.. Much of the world's attention has focused on the trade spat between the U.S. and China. But another trade war is brewing in Asia: between the U.S. and India.

title: Supreme Court Declines to Set Limits on Political Gerrymandering
summary: Conservative justices say such cases present political questions that courts can't decide. WASHINGTON-Federal judges have no authority to correct partisan gerrymandering, the Supreme Court ruled Thursday in a 5-to-4 decision that allows politicians to keep drawing electoral districts that entrench their power unless state law or Congress prevents them from doing so.

title: 'Rockonomics' Review: Making Money in the Music Biz
summary: With recording income in flux these days, performers now rely primarily on concert revenue. Ticket prices have risen accordingly.. 'Music is arguably one of the best bargains ever created," writes Alan B. Krueger in "Rockonomics," his study of the music industry in these rapidly evolving times. The average American, notes Krueger, a professor of economics at Princeton until his death in March, listens to music three to four hours every day, yet spends less than a dime on recorded music for the privilege. (We spend more on unused health-club memberships, apparently.) If music is so cheap, how do people make money from it?

title: Religious Suppression North of the Border
summary: American politicians shouldn't be afraid to stand up for the faithful in Canada.. One of New York state's great civic leaders once began a meeting by observing that I wore a yarmulke at work. I'd just been nominated as president of New York's economic development agency. I told him that headgear hadn't seemed to hinder Cardinal Edward Egan's effectiveness. We got down to business and got along fine. This incident came to mind last week when the National Assembly of Quebec passed a law barring public employees from wearing religious clothing or symbols at work.

title: A Sports Chief's Wine Country Ranch
summary: This luxurious property was owned by Lamar Hunt, the late Kansas City Chiefs founder who is widely credited with coining the term 'Superbowl'.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Notable & Quotable: Chief Justice Roberts in Rucho v. Common Cause
summary: 'We have no commission to allocate political power and influence in the absence of a constitutional directive.'. From Chief Justice John Roberts's majority opinion in Rucho v. Common Cause, June 27:

title: The Contradictions of John Roberts
summary: The Chief draws a road map for politicizing administrative law.. Chief Justice John Roberts is the Supreme Court's new swing vote, and he's proving he won't be pinned down by the law or judicial philosophy. His decision to join the four liberal Justices on Thursday to block a citizenship question on the Census is wrong on the merits and threatens larger damage to the Constitution's separation of powers.

title: The Constitutional Call on Gerrymanders
summary: The Justices are wise to step away from policing partisan redistricting.. The Supreme Court wisely avoided bumbling into a political thicket Thursday, holding in a 5-4 decision that it isn't the judiciary's role to police partisan gerrymandering. The majority opinion by Chief Justice John Roberts is a notable example of judicial restraint, and over the long run it will protect the High Court's credibility.

title: Wayfair's Wayward Walkout
summary: What's the point of denying furniture for detained migrants?. One depressing sign of our times is the politicization of every corner of American life, and the latest outrage overkill involves, well, furniture sales. A classic example of progressives losing the plot is this week's walkout at Wayfair.

title: 'The Last Czars' Review: Deadly Delusions
summary: Netflix's series looks at the final days of the Romanovs and the hubris that contributed to their downfall. There's much about "The Last Czars" (Wednesday, Netflix), a vivid and transporting documentary with dramatizations, that has a distinctly modern feel. That's notwithstanding the fact that it's mainly concerned with Czar Nicholas II (portrayed by Robert Jack) and his czarina, Alexandra (Susanna Herbert), and all five of their children, who ended up slaughtered in a cellar-in a grim building named, significantly, the House of Special Purpose-along with their small retinue of servants in July 1918. They had been killed in a bloody massacre of bizarrely extended length-the family members' hoard of jewelry, secreted under their clothing, served as nearly impenetrable armor-by a Bolshevik assassination squad under orders from higher-ups determined that every last member of the Romanov family dynasty be eradicated in the interest of the Revolution.

title: No Time to Go Cold on Conagra
summary: Investors shouldn't worry too much about Thursday's stumble at Conagra, which is among the most innovative and cheaply valued U.S. food companies. Another day, another food company gone sour.

title: China to Insist U.S. Lift Huawei Ban as Part of Trade Deal
summary: Xi to present Trump with terms for settling fight, including asking the U.S. to lift all punitive tariffs. OSAKA, Japan-President Xi Jinping of China plans to present President Trump with a set of terms he wants the U.S. to meet before Beijing is ready to settle a market-rattling trade confrontation, raising questions of whether the two leaders will agree to relaunch talks.

title: Apple Design Chief Jony Ive to Depart
summary: Ive will form an independent design company. Apple Inc. said design chief Jony Ive will leave the company later this year to form his own independent design company, marking the end of an era at the iPhone maker as it shifts from an emphasis on product development to services.

title: Weinstein Brings on New Lawyers for Sex-Crimes Trial
summary: New attorney Donna Rotunno, who opposes the #MeToo movement, says she hoped to encourage women to take responsibility for their actions. Harvey Weinstein has hired two Chicago-based criminal defense attorneys to represent him in his coming Manhattan sex-crimes trial, court documents show, in the latest shake-up of the Hollywood producer's legal team.

title: Ford to Slash Jobs as Part of European Shake-Up
summary: Auto maker plans to close some plants and reduce shifts at others. BERLIN- Ford Motor Co. laid out plans to close factories in Europe and cut 12,000 jobs, or more than 20% of its European workforce, aiming to return to a profit in the region and focus on technologies that are reshaping the auto industry.

title: Bond Fight Pits Main Street Against Wall Street
summary: Jane Street Capital, United Church of Christ and San Bernardino County are part of a bond-market insurgency fighting a regulatory proposal they say will skew trading in favor of large Wall Street firms. A rebellion is brewing in the $9 trillion corporate-bond market. An unlikely alliance of municipal treasurers, algorithmic-trading specialists and individual investors are fighting a regulatory proposal they say would unfairly benefit firms that have long dominated the bond world.

title: Supreme Court Blocks Citizenship Question From 2020 Census for Now
summary: Trump administration's official explanation for adding the question 'seems to have been contrived,' according to the majority opinion. WASHINGTON-A deeply divided Supreme Court halted the Trump administration's plans to ask U.S. residents on the 2020 census whether they are citizens, in a ruling Thursday that voiced blunt concerns about the White House's motivations.

title: Iran Threatens to Pull Out of Nuclear Treaty, Like North Korea
summary: The warning marked the first time Tehran has explicitly used its participation in the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty as leverage in talks with Europeans on the separate 2015 nuclear deal. Iran raised the stakes in its standoff with the U.S. and Europe on Thursday, warning that if the 2015 nuclear agreement unravels, it would follow the path of North Korea and quit a treaty aimed at stopping the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Twitter to Flag Officials' Tweets That Break Rules
summary: New oversight of politicians, government leaders comes amid rising calls to curb hate speech, misinformation on social media. Twitter Inc. said it would begin flagging tweets by government officials and political figures world-wide who violate its rules, a response to criticism of its oversight that could set the company up for new controversy.

title: The Best Apps for Instantly Identifying Birds and Beasts
summary: These three free apps help birdwatchers and other nature fans find out exactly what they're looking at...fast. If you've ever hiked through the woods with one of those savants who can identify every plant, every tree, every berry, bug and birdsong, you know it can be a revelation. When we're alone in the trees with our ignorance, however, nature remains an inscrutable beauty.

title: FDA Says Medtronic Insulin Pumps Pose Cybersecurity Risk
summary: Hackers could potentially connect wirelessly to a nearby insulin pump to change settings or control insulin delivery. WASHINGTON-The Food and Drug Administration warned that certain insulin pumps made by Medtronic PLC have cybersecurity vulnerabilities and could be manipulated by hackers, causing danger to diabetes patients.

title: North Carolina Regulators Seize Control of Life Insurers Owned by Greg Lindberg
summary: Mr. Lindberg was indicted in April on criminal charges of conspiring to bribe a regulator. North Carolina's insurance department on Thursday took control of a group of troubled life insurers owned by indicted entrepreneur Greg Lindberg.

title: 'The Loudest Voice' Review: A Fox in the Hen House
summary: A series about Roger Ailes paints the ideological executive as a power-hungry malefactor surrounded by virtuous underlings.. By the midpoint of "The Loudest Voice" (Sunday, 10 p.m., Showtime), a seven-part series presented as a guide to the rise of the modern Republican Party-an explanation straight from the production notes-Fox News head Roger Ailes (Russell Crowe) has delivered, to a grateful administration, essential political strategy for the pursuit of the war in Iraq. He's managed to undo the peace and tranquility of Garrison, N.Y., where he lives, by transforming the neighborly local paper, which he's purchased, into an organ of hard-right conservative lecturing, and along the way engendered a bitter community battle over property rights.

title: Congo Mine Collapse Kills at Least 19, Glencore Says
summary: Company claims victims at its partially owned Kamoto Copper site were 'illegal' miners. A mine partially owned by Glencore PLC collapsed in the Democratic Republic of Congo on Thursday, killing at least 19 people who were mining illegally, the London-listed company said.

title: Federal Reserve Clears Big Banks to Boost Payouts to Investors
summary: All 18 banks reviewed pass second round of Fed's stress tests. The Federal Reserve said the biggest U.S. banks are healthy enough to start whittling down their capital stockpiles, clearing them to make payouts to investors that exceed their expected profits.

title: Don't Overestimate the Power of Bank Payouts
summary: Banks are boosting dividends and buybacks following their stress tests, but shares could still struggle. The end of June has become a celebratory occasion for big U.S. banks. This is when most shower shareholders with cash payouts following their annual stress tests. Investors should go easy on the champagne this year, though-they will need a clear head for what lies ahead.

title: White Supremacist Propaganda Spreads on Campuses
summary: Incidents involving extremist flyers, posters and stickers used for recruiting jumps 7%, report says. White supremacist propaganda is spreading on U.S. college campuses, with more cases of extremist advertising in spring 2019 than any semester before it, according to a new report from the Anti-Defamation League.

title: Catholics Debate the Future of Priestly Celibacy
summary: A shortage of priests has led to calls to ease rules that have governed the church for centuries. This October, bishops meeting at the Vatican will consider the possibility of ordaining married men to serve as priests in remote parts of the Amazon region. If the Synod of Bishops recommends such a move to ease celibacy rules and Pope Francis approves, it will be the first time in a thousand years that the Roman Catholic Church has routinely ordained married men as priests.

title: Manafort Pleads Not Guilty to 16 State Charges
summary: Former Trump campaign chairman is serving a seven-and-a-half-year sentence at a federal prison. NEW YORK-Paul Manafort pleaded not guilty to 16 criminal charges Thursday in a case in which state prosecutors have accused the former Trump campaign chairman of falsifying business records to illegally obtain millions of dollars in residential mortgages.

title: Democratic Primary Debate Draws 15.3 Million Viewers
summary: Audience for NBC, MSNBC and Telemundo came in slightly below party's first debate of 2016 cycle. About 15.3 million people tuned in to Wednesday night's Democratic primary debate on NBCUniversal's cable and broadcast networks, a large audience that almost matched the ratings bonanza delivered by the party's first debate of the 2016 election cycle.

title: Bank of Mexico Maintains Interest Rates in Split Vote
summary: Risks are still present, the central bank says. MEXICO CITY-The Bank of Mexico kept interest rates unchanged Thursday in a split decision, citing risks for inflation from both domestic and external sources and a worsening outlook for economic growth.

title: Soon Your Phone Will Be Your Driver's License, MetroCard and More
summary: The question isn't if but when your smartphone is going to replace your wallet. Rule: The word "magic" should not be used when referring to technology. E.g., a keyboard isn't magic. It's a keyboard.

title: New York City Jail Plan Is Dividing Communities
summary: A battle is brewing between city officials and residents opposed to closing the Rikers jail complex and building four borough facilities. Across New York City, some community members are pushing back as city leaders lay the groundwork to build four new jails within the next seven years.

title: Social-Media Users Weigh In on First Democratic Debate
summary: Elizabeth Warren drew most Twitter traffic; Hawaii's Tulsi Gabbard was most googled; Bill de Blasio had responses on various platforms. Julián Castro won a burst of attention. Bill de Blasio generated curiosity about his biracial family. Viewers wanted to learn more about Tulsi Gabbard.

title: SpaceX Is Seeking More Capital From Investors
summary: Elon Musk's venture is looking to raise $314 million in latest funding round that would value the company at $31 billion. Elon Musk's Space Exploration Technologies Corp., or SpaceX, is in the middle of another fundraising round, as it tries to ramp up various rocket and spacecraft projects.

title: At NATO Meeting, Pentagon's New Leader Issues Call to Counter Iran
summary: Acting Secretary of Defense Mark Esper praises members for increasing their share of the load to pay for collective defense. BRUSSELS-Acting Secretary of Defense Mark Esper urged North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies on Thursday to join the U.S. in countering what he called Iran's malign activities in the Persian Gulf, in a first outing on the world stage for the former industry executive-turned-Pentagon chief.

title: Senate Passes Measure Taking Aim at Chinese Banks Doing Business With North Korea
summary: Senate voted to bar Chinese banks that do business with North Korea from the U.S. banking system-a new source of friction as President Trump and Xi Jinping prepare to meet. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Senate took aim at Chinese banks that do business with North Korea, with a vote that struck at institutions that U.S. lawmakers view as the chief violators of United Nations sanctions.

title: Real-Estate Developer Howard Hughes Hires Adviser to Explore Possible Sale
summary: CEO says company is pursuing review because its share price has lagged behind performance of the business. Howard Hughes Corp. is exploring strategic options including a possible sale of the company, a move that comes as the real-estate developer has received a chilly reception from Wall Street on its strategy centered on master-planned communities.

title: 'Yesterday': A World With No Beatles
summary: A film imagines a world almost entirely wiped of the British band's catalog, but the end result is little more than a routine romantic comedy.. Director Danny Boyle's "Yesterday" suggests a number of Beatles titles. "You Can't Do That." "Run for Your Life." And, mostly, "Help!" Any movie that champions the Beatles is on the righteously right track. ("Anyone who is against the Beatles is against life," a character in a now-forgotten film once muttered, memorably.) The story is based on such an audacious idea it should almost be granted immunity from prosecution. But how did such a crazy premise-a world in which the Beatles basically have never existed-turn into such a routine romantic comedy? To paraphrase John Lennon, Mr. Boyle should have known better.

title: 'Maiden' Review: Women Making Waves
summary: A documentary tells the story of the first all-female crew to race a yacht around the world.. The big mystery surrounding the euphoric "Maiden" is why it's taken 30 years to arrive at its destination. In a film world hungry for great material, especially "based on a true story" stories, this one would seem irresistible: An all-female crew in a virtually all-male sport challenges the open ocean, and a sea of presumptions, to prove that women can sail-and take their lives in their hands-just as crazily as men. Not only is it an epic tale about human women waging war against Mother Nature, two members of the team videotaped the entire trip. What in the world were people not thinking?

title: 'Midsommar' Review: Horror in the Summer Sun
summary: Director Ari Aster-of last year's harrowing 'Hereditary'-delivers a disorienting, boldly original film set at a Swedish solstice celebration.. It hasn't quite been an all-sequel summer at the multiplex-some remakes have slipped in, too. Basically, the studios have been treating audiences like newborns (formula, round the clock). So when a movie like "Midsommar" comes along, and goes out of its way to so flamboyantly flout convention, it deserves credit just for being undefinable.

title: 'The Quiet One' Review: A Humble Rock 'n' Roller
summary: Bill Wyman, a longtime but virtually invisible member of the Rolling Stones, gets a pleasingly modest documentary treatment in Oliver Murray's new film.. Bill Wyman, the subject of director Oliver Murray's "The Quiet One" and the self-admitted "stone face" of the original Rolling Stones, managed to be a member of the world's most famous/infamous rock 'n' roll band for 30 years while remaining virtually invisible. "If you do the right thing," he says of playing bass guitar, "you don't get noticed." Which is as close to blowing his own horn as Mr. Wyman seems likely to come.

title: Sapphire Reserve Strains JPMorgan's Ties With United Airlines
summary: Bank faces tough balancing act: promoting its own card while keeping happy airline partner that wants more money for miles. For about three years, Al Sanzari carried two JPMorgan Chase & Co. credit cards: a United Airlines card and the Sapphire Reserve.

title: The Fantasy Utility Vehicle: A $300,000 Nostalgia Trip
summary: Would you drop $300k on that 4x4 you craved in high school? Automotive artisans are retrofitting classic off-roaders-from Ford Broncos to Toyota Land Cruisers-with cutting-edge engineering and prices that cut deep. BETTER BUCKLE your chinstrap: This is a story about people-mostly dudes-spending hundreds of thousands of dollars and waiting years, in some cases, for handbuilt restoration-modernizations (hereafter resto-mods) of 1950s-1980s 4x4s-Toyota Land Cruisers, International Scouts, Land Rover Defenders, Ford Broncos, Willys Wagons, Jeep Cherokees-jacked up like a wrestling-team strength coach and rumbling like Vulcan's very bowels.

title: Florida Red Tide Blamed for 174 Dolphin Deaths
summary: Mammals can receive neurotoxins produced by algae bloom by moving through contaminated water and consuming fish with those toxins. A prolonged algae bloom in the waters off the coast of western Florida in 2018 is to blame for the deaths of 174 bottlenose dolphins, according to newly-released data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: Transat Accepts Takeover Offer From Air Canada
summary: Deal would leave Canada two main carriers offering domestic and international travel. The board at Canadian travel and tour company Transat A.T. Inc. agreed to a takeover by Air Canada, at a price below what another bidder has offered.

title: Democrats' Comments Give Health-Care Stocks a Stronger Pulse
summary: Moves come after sector has lagged behind the broader market in 2019. Beaten-down health-care stocks saw some relief Thursday, a day after most Democratic presidential candidates shied away from forcefully endorsing plans to nationalize the U.S. health-insurance industry.

title: 'The Waverly Gallery' Review: A Playwright of the Smaller Stage
summary: Shakespeare & Company's production of Kenneth Lonergan's memory play proves that his subtle, richly wrought work is best-suited to intimate spaces..

title: Inflation Bonds Rally Without Inflation, Signaling Fed Bets
summary: Yields on Treasury inflation-protected securities have declined to near their lowest levels in almost two years. Demand is surging for U.S. government bonds that have returns adjusted for the rate of inflation, even as investors have grown increasingly skeptical about the potential for prices to rise, the latest sign that many expect interest-rate cuts from the Federal Reserve.

title: Stocks Rise as Investors Hope for Trade Progress
summary: Dow is weighed down by Boeing; government bond yields decline. U.S. stocks rose Thursday, with the S&P 500 snapping a four-day losing streak, as investors hope for progress on the trade between the U.S. and China.

title: Russia Says It Won't Increase Presence in Venezuela
summary: Moscow's support for Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has been an irritant in its relations with Washington. Russia said it had rotated a group of weapons specialists in Venezuela and emphasized that it didn't intend to increase its military presence in the Latin American country.

title: 'Doomsday' Math Says Humanity May Have Just 760 Years Left
summary: An 18th-century equation that powers today's computer algorithms also predicts the demise of humankind. Is humanity doomed? We certainly don't lack apocalyptic scenarios: nuclear war, a robot uprising, out-of-control climate change. Unlikely, far-fetched? Not according to scientists and mathematicians who, in recent decades, have found a surprising new source for anxiety about the long-term survival of the human race: probability theory. The so-called "doomsday argument" holds that there is a 50% chance that the end of human life will come within 760 years.

title: Liberalism Has Evolved-How Liberal Is It?
summary: Affirmative action has morphed into diversity and identity politics, with each aggrieved group fighting, often among each other, for its piece of the economic and political pies.. Despite Michael Blechman's arguments ("Liberalism Isn't What It Used to Be," op-ed, June 21), the values that made my father a great leader resonate powerfully today. Robert Kennedy dedicated his life to principles like justice and civil rights and to healing the sharp divisions in our society. He believed in the force that comes from acting on these ideals, ripples of hope that he said could "sweep down the mightiest walls of oppression and resistance."

title: Gold Loses Some Luster Ahead of Summit
summary: Investors said clarity provided by trade agreement between the U.S. and China would likely weigh on gold. Gold prices retreated from multiyear highs, as investors awaited the outcome of trade discussions between U.S. and Chinese leaders at the Group of 20 summit this weekend.

title: What Principle Limits Our Public Unions?
summary: Your editorial "Nevada Embraces Public Unions" (June 21) the obvious calculus of significant increased costs of government leaves one to wonder-where were the voters?. Regarding your editorial "Nevada Embraces Public Unions" (Review & Outlook, June 21): The obvious calculus of significant increased costs of government leaves one to wonder: Where were the voters?

title: Wood Is a Natural 24-Hour Renewable Fuel
summary: Bioenergy should be a bigger part of an all-in strategy to reduce carbon emissions and limit dependence on fossil fuels.. "A Logjam in Fire-Weary Paradise" (U.S. News, June 15) highlights a major problem in California-and a clear opportunity. California should follow the lead of Europe and Japan-and the recommendation of the U.N.'s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change-and promote the use of renewable wood energy. Bioenergy, in the form of wood pellets, uses wood that otherwise isn't wanted or isn't usable by timber companies. This includes the type of wood that is stacking up around California communities, as well as the so-called thinnings and underbrush that need to be removed to ensure healthy forests and fewer fires.

title: Joe Biden Will Govern to the Left
summary: I don't think Joe Biden would govern as a moderate if elected president nor do I see any real differences between him and the other Democratic hopefuls.. Regarding your editorial "The Democratic Opportunity" (June 26): Joe Biden has been an adept follower but never a leader throughout his political career. I don't think he would govern as a moderate if elected president nor do I see any real differences between him and the other Democratic hopefuls on regulation, taxes, climate, abortion, immigration, foreign policy, trade, gun rights or free speech.

title: Boeing Looks to Settle 737 MAX Crash Claims
summary: Some families suing over Ethiopian Airlines accident push for jury trial. Boeing Co. is negotiating settlements with the families of dozens of victims of two crashes involving 737 MAX jetliners, while some plaintiffs' attorneys push for a jury trial to air details of the accidents.

title: Billionaire Catsimatidis Buys Conservative AM Radio Station
summary: Supermarket magnate launched talk show on local radio after failed run for GOP mayoral nomination in 2013. Supermarket magnate John Catsimatidis, whose Sunday morning radio talk show has become part of the New York City political firmament, has acquired conservative radio station 77 WABC from Cumulus Media Inc.

title: A Debate Warning for Democrats
summary: Warren wants to eliminate private health insurance.. A primary campaign is the fight for a party's nomination but it also lays the political ground for the general election. On that point, the most important moment of the first presidential debate Wednesday night came when Sen. Elizabeth Warren raised her hand to say she would eliminate private health insurance.

title: How Jam-Packed Will My Train Be? Google Says It Has the Answer
summary: New feature in Google Maps promises to tell commuters how crowded buses and trains will be. If you knew your regular, jam-packed commuter train is usually followed by another one with empty seats, would you leave home 15 minutes later?

title: Lamar Hunt's Napa Valley Ranch Asks $19.95 Million
summary: The late Kansas City Chiefs founder and his wife Norma Hunt bought the 40-acre property in 2000 and built it from scratch. A 40-acre California wine country ranch previously owned by Lamar Hunt, the late Kansas City Chiefs founder who is widely credited with coining the term "Super Bowl," is going on the market for $19.95 million.

title: Offstage in Miami, Democratic Candidates Search for Spotlight
summary: The presidential hopefuls who will be in Thursday's debate-or didn't make either stage-did their best Wednesday to get attention in the spin room and on the airwaves. MIAMI-As 10 Democrats vying for their presidential nomination competed in the first debate of the 2020 cycle, 10 more did their best to pass the time, waiting for their turn.

title: Wondery Raises $10 Million to Take Podcasts Global
summary: New investment values largest independent podcast network at over $100 million.

title: Pelosi Calls for Surgical Changes to Trump Trade Pact
summary: Democratic House Speaker voices enforceability concerns about new North American trade agreement. WASHINGTON-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said that the pending U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement may need to be reopened and changed with surgical precision before the House will vote on the trade pact.

title: Greece's Voters Turn to Establishment Amid Europe's Populist Wave
summary: Pro-business scion of a political dynasty seeks to replace upstart Syriza party. ATHENS-Greece is expected to elect a conservative leader from an eminent political family next month-and become the first European country in recent times to revert to its establishment after being led by populist outsiders.

title: Best-Selling Books Week Ended June 22
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: State Street to Pay $88 Million Settlement for Overcharging Clients
summary: SEC alleges the firm's bank-and-trust division had overbilled clients by $170 million. State Street Corp. agreed to pay $88 million to settle the top U.S. securities regulator's allegations that the custody bank overcharged its investment-firm clients.

title: Conagra Sales Fall Short of Targets
summary: Weaker performance reported as competitors undercut some of the company's key brands on price. Conagra Brands Inc. joined the list of food makers disclosing disappointing results, after competitors, including Kraft Heinz Co., undercut several of its key brands on price.

title: Rex Tillerson Says Jared Kushner Often Kept Him Out of the Loop
summary: Former secretary of state testified in front of congressional panel in May; transcript was released Thursday. WASHINGTON-Former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson told Congress that he was often blindsided by Jared Kushner's foreign-policy efforts as President Trump's son-in-law worked independently, according to a transcript of testimony released Thursday.

title: In Miami, There Are Too Many Condos and Not Enough Foreign Buyers
summary: An exodus of Latin Americans is exacerbating oversupply at the high-end, but local real estate players are banking on U.S. buyers fleeing high-tax states to give the market a much needed boost. After being kidnapped seven years ago, Juerg Degenmann decided to move his family from Venezuela to Miami for increased security. Long a playground for Venezuelan elites, the Florida city seemed like a natural choice, especially since Mr. Degenmann already owned a vacation home there, and he had bought and sold several investment properties in the area.

title: Financier Bill Browder Plays the Long Game to Expose Russian Money-Laundering
summary: The Hermitage Capital Management CEO says he isn't deterred by European investigators who have declined to open probes at his request. AUSTIN, Texas-Several of the recent corporate sagas involving allegations of money-laundering at European banks have featured a central character: Bill Browder, the American-born financier who has been on a decade-long campaign to expose Russian corruption.

title: Castro, Seeking to Break Out, Says 'People Are Looking at Me in a New Way'
summary: Former secretary of Housing and Urban Development went on attack in Democratic presidential debate. WASHINGTON-Julián Castro needed a breakout moment in Wednesday night's Democratic debate, and he may have gotten one.

title: Maersk CEO Wants Half Its Earnings to Come From Inland Logistics
summary: Danish shipping giant is looking at supply-chain investments to boost its sagging revenue. The world's biggest commercial shipping operator plans to add extensive new capacity-but it won't be on the water.

title: Ralph Rucci Returns to Haute Couture (With a $27,000 Silk Raincoat)
summary: Despite intimations of couture's demise, the New York-based designer goes back to his true calling.. "God said, 'You are going back to the couture. You have to do this,' " he says, between sips of watermelon juice served by his house assistant, Jacek Ratkowski, in his brown-on-brown Upper East Side living room, as decorated by close friend and client Susan Gutfreund with Chinese antiques and Elsa Peretti objets.

title: How to Buy a Wedding Band Without Talking to Anyone
summary: Brothers Daniel and Ben Mardkha started their company Marke to reinvent how men shop for wedding bands: "We wanted to gut out all the lovey-dovey stuff". The wedding band company Marke values one thing above all else: ease. When its founders, brothers Daniel and Ben Mardkha, realized how many men don't know what they're doing when the time comes to buy a ring, they set out to remove guesswork and confusion. Or at least, move it to their living room.

title: Rachel Maddow's Reality Check
summary: A Democratic presidential candidate reveals that voters don't share her agenda.. One of the wonderful things about America and the fragmentation of modern media is that it's possible to be a highly compensated television anchor while speaking for a tiny sliver of the American electorate. But perhaps MSNBC's Rachel Maddow didn't expect this fact to be highlighted during a gathering of Democratic presidential candidates.

title: Chemicals Giant BASF to Cut 5% of Global Workforce

title: The Magic of Footprints in Wet Sand
summary: The small particles in granular materials don't behave like ordinary solids.. Early mornings on a quiet beach are one of the greatest joys of summer. On a recent trip to the south coast of the U.K., I got up early every day to spend time on the beach. As I walked on the glistening ribbon of wet sand at the water's edge, each step produced a patch of dry sand that expanded outward from my foot for a few inches, and then disappeared as I moved on, leaving only my footprint behind. If I had been walking on a giant wet sponge, I'd have created a small flood with each step as water was squeezed out. But that's not the way sand works. Each step was an invitation into the weird world of granular materials: the solids that don't behave.
